text: What does it mean "the system has a trivial solution"?
answerOptions: All leading variables in the solution are 0
The system has a single solution
The linear structures that represented by the equations are intersecting in the origin
correctAnswer: All leading variables in the solution are 0
The linear structures that represented by the equations are intersecting in the origin

text: Is $$(x, y) = (3, 0)$$ a solution of this system? $$\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 5 \\ 4x - y = 1 \end{cases}$$
solution: $$(x, y) = (3, 0)$$ it's a solution only of the first of the two equations

text: Consider the equation $$x + y + 1 = 0$$.
solution: It is linear as all the leading variables are in the power of 1 and it is homogeneous as the constant term is 0

text: The following linear system is $$\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 5 \\ 4x - y = 1 \end{cases}$$
solution: The system has a single solution $$(x, y) = (\frac{4}{7}, \frac{9}{7})$$, so it is consistent and the constant terms are not 0.

text: An equation corresponds to a ...
Each row of the augmented matrix corresponds to an equation of the linear system
Each column of the augmented matrix corresponds to an equation of the linear system
What is the correct solution of the linear system $$\begin{cases} 6x-4y+2z = 3 \\ 6x-4y+2z = 2 \end{cases}$$
answerOptions: It does not have a real solution
correctAnswer: It does not have a real solution
solution: The equations are identical in everything but constant term, so the lines do not intersect

text: What is the correct solution of the linear system $$\begin{cases} -2x + y = 3 \\ 3x - y = 1 \end{cases}$$
answerOptions: It does not have a real solution

text: Select correct matrix, representing the linear system $$\begin{cases} 2y+z-1 = -x \\ 2z = 3-5z \\ 3x+z = 0 \end{cases}$$
Select correct statement(s):
answerOptions: In the solution set we express the leading variables in terms of the free variables
In the solution set we express the free variables in terms of the leading variables
correctAnswer: In the solution set we express the leading variables in terms of the free variables
solution: In the solution set, we express the leading variables in terms of the free variables. This is because the free variables can take any value, and the leading variables are dependent on these values.

text: Select correct statement(s):
answerOptions: A parameter is assigned to all of the free variables
A parameter is assigned to all of the leading variables
correctAnswer: In the solution set we express the leading variables in terms of the free variables. This is because the free variables can take any value, and the leading variables are dependent on these values.

text: Which of the following operations can be performed to the augmented matrix of a linear system while solving the system?
answerOptions: Multiplying a row by any scalar
Multiplying a row by a non-zero scalar
Add a row to a different row
Add to a row a multiple of a different row
Add to a row a multiple of itself
correctAnswer: Multiplying a row by a non-zero scalar
Add a row to a different row
Add to a row a multiple of a different row
solution: All the options are correct apart from the first and sixth as we cannot multiply a row by 0 and we cannot (in general case) add to a row a multiple of itself, as it might nullify the row.

text: Can we perform elementary column operations to the augmented matrix of a linear system while solving the system in the canonical way?
solution: The columns are assigned to variables and hence, we are not allowed to permute them. Note: technically we can permute the columns, but beware that it would change the order of variables, leading to another answer tuple, so it is HIGHLY discouraged.

text: In row echelon form, the first entry in each non-zero row is always 1.
solution: The first entry in each non-zero row is called the leading entry, and it is not necessarily 1.

text: Which of the following statements is true about the row echelon form of a matrix?
answerOptions: The leading entry of each non-zero row is 1
The leading entry of each non-zero row is to the right of the leading entry of the previous row
All entries below a leading entry are zero
correctAnswer: The leading entry of each non-zero row is to the right of the leading entry of the previous row
All entries below a leading entry are zero

text: In row echelon form, the number of non-zero rows is equal to the number of leading variables.
In row echelon form, the leading entry of each non-zero row is to the ... of the leading entry of the previous row.
Row echelon form and reduced row echelon form are...
answerOptions: Only reduced row echelon form is unique
Only row echelon form is unique
correctAnswer: Only reduced row echelon form is unique

text: The number of leading variables is equal to the number of non-zero rows in the row echelon form.
If all variables are leading, the system has a unique solution.
We express the leading variables as a sum of multiples of the free variables and possibly a constant term.

Performing elementary row operations changes the equations but not the common solutions.
Removing a zero row or column affects the solution set of the linear system.
If the row echelon form has a leading 1 in the last (augmented) column, the system is not solvable.

Select the correct order of steps to perform Gauss-Jordan elimination: $$
ewline$$ 1. Multiply the top row by a scalar so that the top row's leading entry becomes 1. $$
ewline$$ 2. Swap the rows so that all rows with all zero entries are on the bottom. $$
ewline$$ 3. Add/subtract multiples of the top row to the other rows so that all other entries in the column containing the top row's leading entry are zero. $$
ewline$$ 4. Swap the rows so that the row with the largest, leftmost nonzero entry is on top. $$
ewline$$ 5. Repeat *some previous steps* for the next leftmost nonzero entry until all the leading entries are 1. $$
ewline$$ 6. Swap the rows so that the leading entry of each nonzero row is to the right of the leading entry of the row above it.
The associated homogeneous linear system is the parallel object (line, plane, etc) through the origin.
The number of free variables is the number of variables minus the number of leading variables.
The number of leading variables is the number of non-zero rows in the row echelon form.
If there are more unknowns than equations, there must be free variables.
If there are more equations than variables, nothing can be said about the system (useless equations).
The order of equations in a system is important.
The solution set of a system of linear equations is the intersection of the solution sets of the individual equations.
If two equations in a system are the same, one of them can be deleted.
Consider the system: $$\begin{cases} 7x + y = 1 \\ x - 2y = 0 \end{cases}$$ Select the correct assertions:
The number of leading variables is at most the number of variables that appear in the equation.
The number of free variables is at most the number of variables that appear in the equation.
Solve the system of equations: $$\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 6 \\ 4x - y = 5 \end{cases}$$
Solve the system of equations: $$\begin{cases} x + 2y + z = 4 \\ 2x - y + 3z = 5 \\ 3x + y - z = 6 \end{cases}$$
Solve the system of equations: $$\begin{cases} 3x + 4y = 10 \\ 5x - 2y = 3 \end{cases}$$
Solve the system of equations: $$\begin{cases} x - y + z = 2 \\ 2x + y - 3z = -1 \\ -x + 4y + 2z = 7 \end{cases}$$
Solve the system of equations: $$\begin{cases} 2x + y - z = 3 \\ x - 2y + 3z = -1 \\ 3x + y + 2z = 4 \end{cases}$$
Perform Gauss-Jordan elimination on the matrix: $$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & -1 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 & -2 & 1 \\ -3 & 1 & 1 & -2 \end{pmatrix}$$
Perform simple Gauss elimination on the matrix: $$\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 & 3 & 4 \\ 1 & 3 & -2 & 1 \\ 3 & 2 & -1 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$$
